sections.title: Conclusion: The Worth of True Righteousness

verses.text: This is a copy of the letter Jeremiah sent to those who were about to be taken as captives to Babylon by the king of the Babylonians, giving them the message the Lord had instructed him.
verses.comment: This introductory verse sets the context for the entire chapter, framing it as a letter from Jeremiah to the exiles with divine authority.

verses.text: Because you have sinned against the Lord, you will be led away to Babylon as captives by Nebuchadnezzar, king of the Babylonians.
verses.comment: This verse attributes the exile to the Israelites' unfaithfulness, a common prophetic theme. Nebuchadnezzar is named as the instrument of God's judgment.

verses.text: Once you arrive in Babylon, you will remain there for many years, for a long period—up to seven generations; after that, I will bring you back in peace.
verses.comment: The number 'seven generations' signifies a complete, long period; ultimately, God's intention is restoration.

verses.text: In Babylon you will witness idols crafted from silver, gold, and wood—carried on people’s shoulders—which the nations fear.
verses.comment: The verse introduces the central theme: critique of idol worship, common in Near Eastern cultures.

verses.text: Be careful not to imitate the foreigners or to be frightened by their gods.
verses.comment: The exiles are warned against adopting pagan practices, reinforcing themes of covenant faithfulness.

verses.text: When you see crowds gathered before and behind them, bowing in worship, remember in your hearts, 'It is the Lord alone we must worship.'
verses.comment: Faithful Jews are encouraged to internalize true worship despite the idolatrous environment.

verses.text: My angel is with you, watching over your lives.
verses.comment: Reference to angelic protection offers comfort and assurance in exile.

verses.text: Craftsmen smooth out the tongues of these idols, covering them with gold and silver, but they are mere fakes, unable to speak.
verses.comment: Idols are portrayed as lifeless, mute objects despite their elaborate decoration.

verses.text: People fashion golden crowns for the heads of their idols, just as one might decorate a beloved young woman with jewelry.
verses.comment: This imagery highlights the absurdity of treating idols with more honor than living beings.

verses.text: At times, priests will even secretly take gold and silver from their idols for their own use.
verses.comment: The verse points out corruption among pagan priests, further undermining the credibility of idol worship.

verses.text: Some is even given as payment to prostitutes on the temple rooftops. The idols are clothed in garments like humans—yet they are only gold, silver, and wood.
verses.comment: Temple prostitution was a feature of some pagan cults; here, the text underscores the shame and futility of idol worship.

verses.text: These idols cannot save themselves from rust or decay. Even when dressed in royal purple,
verses.comment: Despite attempts to glorify them, idols are subject to decay—contrasted with the living God.

verses.text: their faces must be wiped clean because of the thick dust that settles on them in the temple.
verses.comment: Idols need human maintenance, a sign of their impotence.

verses.text: One idol may hold a scepter like a judge, but it is powerless to punish anyone who offends it.
verses.comment: Such idols imitate human authority but have no real power.

verses.text: Another holds a dagger in its right hand and an axe, yet it cannot protect itself from war or thieves.
verses.comment: Idols are depicted as defenseless, in contrast to the true God.

verses.text: It is obvious that these cannot be gods; so do not be afraid of them.
verses.comment: A direct appeal to reject fear of powerless idols.

verses.text: Just as a broken dish is useless,
verses.comment: Analogies are used to emphasize the worthlessness of idols.

verses.text: so are these gods when set up in temples. Their eyes are filled with dust kicked up by the feet of those who enter. As offenders against the king often have all doors secured against them, so priests lock and bar their temples, not for reverence, but to protect their idols from being stolen.
verses.comment: The priests’ efforts to secure the idols highlight their inability to protect themselves.

verses.text: They burn more lamps for these idols than for themselves, though the idols see nothing.
verses.comment: The devotion to lifeless statues is exposed as misguided.

verses.text: They are like a support beam in the temple, but it is said their hearts decay as creeping things from the ground eat them and their robes. Yet they take no notice,
verses.comment: 'Hearts' is possibly ironic; their lifelessness is being emphasized.

verses.text: nor are they aware when their faces turn black from the smoke rising in the temple.
verses.comment: Idols’ inability to react to their environment is further mocked.

verses.text: Bats, swallows, and other birds perch on their bodies and heads, as do cats.
verses.comment: Idols serve as nothing more than perches for animals, underlining their uselessness.

verses.text: From all this you can see that they are not gods; so do not be afraid of them.
verses.comment: A repeated exhortation not to fear idols because of their obvious impotence.

verses.text: As for the gold they use for beauty—it will not shine unless someone wipes away the tarnish. Even when the idols were being molded, they did not realize it.
verses.comment: Without humans, idols would remain neglected and dull—underscoring their powerlessness.

verses.text: They are purchased at high prices, but there is no breath of life in them.
verses.comment: Idols are lifeless despite their monetary value.

verses.text: Since they can't walk, others must carry them on their shoulders—making their uselessness obvious to everyone. And those who serve them are made to look foolish.
verses.comment: Idols need to be carried, a sign of their impotence, while worshipers are shamed.

verses.text: If any of their gods fall to the ground, someone must set them upright. If propped up, they can't move; if knocked over, they can't get back up. Offerings are laid before them like those set before the dead.
verses.comment: Idols are likened to lifeless corpses, needing human help.

verses.text: Priests sell the animals presented as sacrifices to these gods and keep the money for themselves. Their wives salt some of the meat to preserve it, but none is given to the poor or helpless.
verses.comment: The priests and their wives are portrayed as corrupt and self-serving.

verses.text: Women who are ritually unclean—whether menstruating or having just given birth—are permitted to touch the sacrifices. Knowing all this, you can see these are not gods, so have no fear of them.
verses.comment: Ritual impurity would render sacrifices unacceptable in true worship, pointing to the emptiness of idolatry.

verses.text: How can they be called gods? Women prepare their food for these silver, gold, and wooden images;
verses.comment: The fact that women serve these idols highlights their utter powerlessness.

verses.text: and inside their temples, priests sit wearing torn clothes, with their heads and beards shaved and their heads uncovered.
verses.comment: Pagan mourning rituals further display the futility and emptiness of idol worship.

verses.text: They cry out and wail before their gods as people do at funeral feasts.
verses.comment: The comparison with funeral wailing emphasizes the lifeless nature of idols.

verses.text: The priests take some of the idols' clothing and use it to dress their wives and children.
verses.comment: Idol worship leads to further impurity and self-interest among the priests.

verses.text: No matter if someone harms or helps them, idols cannot repay either evil or good. They have no power to install or remove rulers.
verses.comment: Idols can't affect human affairs or politics.

verses.text: They can't give wealth or riches; nor, if someone fails to fulfill a vow, can they demand repayment.
verses.comment: The impotence of idols is also seen in their inability to enforce pledges.

verses.text: They cannot rescue anyone from death or protect the helpless from the strong.
verses.comment: Idols are contrasted with God, who rescues and defends the weak.

verses.text: They cannot give sight to the blind or offer deliverance to anyone in distress.
verses.comment: Another point on the inability of idols to perform miracles.

verses.text: They don't show compassion to widows or kindness to orphans.
verses.comment: The true God is provider to the vulnerable; idols are not.

verses.text: These objects—crafted from timber and then covered with gold and silver—are no more than rocks from the mountains. Those who worship them will end in disgrace.
verses.comment: Calling idols 'stones from the mountain' highlights their created nature.

verses.text: Why should anyone think they are gods or give them that name? The Foolishness of Worshiping Idols Even the Chaldeans treat them with no respect—when they encounter someone mute, they bring them to Bel, hoping the idol will make them speak, as if Bel could understand or act!
verses.comment: This verse introduces a new section, explicitly mocking the irrationality of idol worship.

verses.text: But the idols are oblivious, and the people do not turn away from these false gods; truly, they lack all understanding.
verses.comment: Spiritual blindness keeps idol worshipers from perceiving the truth.

verses.text: Women with cords tied around them sit along the temple passageways, burning bran as incense.
verses.comment: Refers to pagan temple prostitution rituals and associated offerings.

verses.text: When one of these women is taken aside by a passing man and lies with him, she mocks the woman next to her for not being chosen and for not having her cord broken.
verses.comment: This points to rivalry and shame among women involved in idolatrous temple practices.

verses.text: Everything done for these idols is empty ritual. Why should anyone believe they are gods or call them gods?
verses.comment: The repetitive argument underscores the absurdity of idol worship.

verses.text: They are made by carpenters and goldsmiths, and can be nothing except what their makers want them to be.
verses.comment: Their human origin is emphasized as a reason against worshiping them.

verses.text: The craftsmen who make them will not live long themselves;
verses.comment: Makes the point that even the makers are mortal, so their creations must be less.

verses.text: so how can objects made by these men be gods? Their idols leave behind only falsehood and scorn for those who come after.
verses.comment: Idols become a legacy of deception and disgrace.

verses.text: When war or disaster threatens, the priests huddle together to decide where they can hide themselves and their gods.
verses.comment: Idols need to be 'saved' by humans—a reversal of what is expected of gods.

verses.text: How can anyone doubt that these are not gods, since they cannot save themselves in times of war or trouble?
verses.comment: No one with sense should believe in such powerless objects.

verses.text: Since they are only wood, covered in gold and silver, it will be known later that they are false.
verses.comment: Their true nature will eventually be evident to all.

verses.text: All nations and kings will see that these are not gods but merely things made by people, and that there is nothing divine about them.
verses.comment: Idols are the work of human hands, not the Creator.

verses.text: Who, then, could possibly think they are gods?
verses.comment: A rhetorical question emphasizing the pointlessness of idol worship.

verses.text: They cannot install a king in any land or send rain for the people.
verses.comment: Only God controls nature and human affairs.

verses.text: They can't decide matters of justice or rescue someone who is wronged, for they have no power at all.
verses.comment: True divine power includes judgment and deliverance—both lacking in idols.

verses.text: These idols are like crows that fly between heaven and earth. When a fire breaks out in the temple, the priests escape and save themselves, but the idols are burned like logs.
verses.comment: Idols are abandoned in danger, further showing they lack power.

verses.text: They can't oppose a king or enemy. So why consider them gods?
verses.comment: The logical conclusion: these objects are not worthy of worship.

verses.text: False gods, made of wood and covered in silver and gold, cannot save themselves from thieves or robbers.
verses.comment: Idols are easily plundered, showing their helplessness.

verses.text: Anyone can take from them their gold, silver, or robes and leave with the spoils, while the idols are powerless to stop it.
verses.comment: This again mocks their inability to provide protection—even for themselves.

verses.text: It is better to be a valiant king, or even a simple tool that is useful to its owner, than to be these counterfeit gods; better even the door of a house that guards its contents, or a wooden column in a palace, than to be these idols.
verses.comment: A hierarchy of usefulness: even inanimate household objects serve a purpose, unlike idols.

verses.text: The sun, moon, and stars shine with brilliance and obey when they are sent by God.
verses.comment: True celestial bodies obey God's will, unlike idols, which are powerless.

verses.text: The lightning’s flash is seen far and wide, and the wind blows everywhere as God orders.
verses.comment: Natural forces respond to God, showing God's true power in creation.

verses.text: When God commands, the clouds traverse the world just as He has ordered.
verses.comment: Creation’s obedience to God is contrasted with idols’ complete powerlessness.

verses.text: Fire sent from above to burn up mountains and forests does what it is commanded. But these idols are nothing like that, neither in appearance nor in power.
verses.comment: The phenomenon of lightning (fire from above) again points to God’s might.

verses.text: So you should not think these are gods or call them gods, for they cannot judge disputes or show kindness to anyone.
verses.comment: A final warning not to honor idols with divine titles.

verses.text: Now that you know these are not gods, do not fear them.
verses.comment: The end of the polemic: grounding readers in right knowledge.

verses.text: They cannot curse or bless kings;
verses.comment: Only God has true authority to bless or curse.

verses.text: They can’t reveal signs in the sky for the nations, shine with the sun's light, or illuminate like the moon.
verses.comment: Idols fail to influence the heavens, another sign of their impotence.

verses.text: Even wild animals are better, for at least they can escape and protect themselves.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the utter uselessness of idols—even animals have more capability.

verses.text: There is absolutely no evidence that these are gods. So do not fear them.
verses.comment: Comes to the final verdict: these objects are not divine.

verses.text: They're like a scarecrow in a cucumber patch, unable to guard anything—so are these wooden gods overlaid with gold and silver.
verses.comment: The scarecrow imagery devalues the idol’s role as protector.

verses.text: In the same way, these gods are like a thornbush in a garden where every bird sits, or like a corpse thrown into the darkness.
verses.comment: Further analogies stress the uselessness and indignity of idols.

verses.text: As the purple and linen clothes rot on them, you'll see for yourself that these are not gods—they'll eventually rot away and bring disgrace upon the land.
verses.comment: Decay and disgrace are the final destinies of idols.

verses.text: A righteous person without idols is far better; such a person stands above reproach.
verses.comment: The closing contrast: upright living is superior to idol worship.
verses.sectionHeader: Conclusion: The Worth of True Righteousness
